The first statement is a conditional statement: "If the cake was chocolate, then the muffins were blueberry." In logical terms, this can be represented as "If P, then Q," where P is "the cake was chocolate" and Q is "the muffins were blueberry."

The second statement is "The cake was chocolate," which corresponds to P being true.

In logic, when we have a conditional statement "If P, then Q" and we know that P is true, we can use a rule called "modus ponens" to conclude that Q must also be true. Modus ponens is a valid form of argument that allows us to infer the truth of the consequent (Q) when the antecedent (P) is true.

Therefore, given the conditional statement and the fact that the antecedent is true, we can logically infer that the consequent is also true.
